abstract: “Two-and-twenty” has been a rule of thumb for management fees in the venture capital industry. Fund managers get twenty percent of any profits they generate and two percent of total assets under management in fees. Is it time for venture capital to do the same?
snippet: “Two-and-twenty” has been a rule of thumb for management fees in the venture capital industry. Fund managers get twenty percent of any profits they generate and two percent of total assets under management in fees. Is it time for venture capital t...
lead_paragraph: For more than a generation, “two-and-twenty” has been a rule of thumb for management fees in the venture capital industry. It means fund managers get 20 percent of any profits they generate and 2 percent of total assets under management in fees. Private equity is starting to get the hint. Is it time, wonders VentureBeat, for venture capital to do the same?

headline.main: Is It Time for Venture Capital’s “Two-and-Twenty” to End?

In several states the alliance held rallies and news conferences and showed commercials, all meant to shore up sympathetic legislators — and put pressure on less sympathetic ones. abstract: Dick Berg, the veteran movie and television writer and producer, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 87, according to members of his family.
snippet: Dick Berg, the veteran movie and television writer and producer, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 87, according to members of his family.
lead_paragraph: Dick Berg, the long-time movie and television writer and producer, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 87, according to members of his family. Mr. Berg, who was born in New York, started his Hollywood career as a dialogue coach for Roy Rogers and other cowboy-actors. Mr. Berg returned to New York in the 1950s, and worked his way into television by writing dramas for the Kraft Theater, Robert Montgomery Presents, Studio One, and Playhouse 90. Back in Hollywood later, he began working on scripts for MGM and Fox, but really made his mark as television writer-producer. He produced the “Checkmate” detective series for Universal, then went on to make dozens of television movies, among them “Wallenberg,” “The Martian Chronicles” and “A Rumor of War.” Mr. Berg’s survivors include Jeff Berg, the chairman of International Creative Management, and Scott Berg, the author of “Max Perkins: Editor of Genius,” “Goldywn: A Biography” and “Lindbergh.”

headline.main: Dick Berg, Longtime Writer-Producer, Dies at 87

lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t believe how often greenscreen effects show up in movies these days. Heard of it? That’s where, while filming, the actors perform in front of a wall (or an entire set) that’s been painted solid bright green. abstract: Historical numbers show the gradual, economywide shift away from traditional defined benefit plans and toward defined contribution plans.
snippet: Historical numbers show the gradual, economywide shift away from traditional defined benefit plans and toward defined contribution plans.
lead_paragraph: I have an article today that discusses how a retirement system based on private savings is affecting the job market. In short, when the economy is contracting, and employers are trying to shrink their payrolls, older workers cling to their jobs because their nest eggs have shrunk. In other words, as Prof. Teresa Ghilarducci at New School put it, 401(k)’s act as a sort of “reverse automatic stabilizer” for the economy.

lead_paragraph: There's plenty of nastiness on the Internet--mean stuff, dirty stuff, snarky stuff--but there's also an incredible amount of kindness and support to be found. Next time you're looking for something wildly entertaining and enlightening to do online, check out a site like answers.yahoo.com or answerbag.com. On these sites, you can pose a question--any question at all--and crowdsource the answer. You watch and wait as the vast masses chime in with their opinions on your questions.

abstract: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting.
snippet: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting.
lead_paragraph: The European Union threatened to impose tariffs against Iran, Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates on a material used in plastic bottles, saying European producers may be victims of subsidies and price undercutting. The European Union opened investigations into whether manufacturers of polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, in those areas receive excessive government aid and sell in the 27-nation bloc below cost, a practice known as dumping. PET users include plastic-bottle mold makers and bottlers including Coca-Cola. Under European Union practices, the commission can impose provisional antisubsidy duties for four months and provisional antidumping penalties for six months.

headline.main: Sanctions Threatened Against Plastics Producers

abstract: Writers Guild says there were fewer writers in Hollywood in 2008, and they made less money.
snippet: Writers Guild says there were fewer writers in Hollywood in 2008, and they made less money.
lead_paragraph: The Writers Guild of America, West, said its members saw earnings reported to the guild drop 17.9 percent to $801.4 million in 2008, while the number of writers reporting income fell 9.7 percent to 4,163. The year was affected by a three-month writers strike that began late in 2007. According to the guild’s annual report, television earnings fell 3.1 percent to $437.5 million, while feature film earnings dropped $30.7 percent to $361 million. The television drop was similar to a decline in the previous year, but feature income had risen sharply in 2007, as studios hurried film projects and stockpiled scripts in anticipation of the strike. The guild reported just $2.9 million in writers’ income from radio news, informational writing and interactive work, down 17.1 percent from 2007.

headline.main: Hollywood Writers Were Fewer and Made Less in 2008

lead_paragraph: Credit cards have gotten a lot of attention lately. Mr. Shane cites a study by an entrepreneurial research group that says that every $1,000 of credit card debt a business takes on increases the chances of failure by 2.2 percent. Seems rather obvious.

lead_paragraph: If Skype becomes the biggest thing since Facebook — and it just might — it will be because of people like, well, me. People who resisted it for years, thinking that the cost of phone calling had gotten so low anyway that free was unnecessary. People who might have had a bad experience with Skype years ago, before its sound was as crystal clear as it has since become. People who had kids traveling abroad — as both my sons did this summer — and suddenly found Skype a godsend. And now I’m hooked on it.

abstract: Biogen, the maker of medicines for multiple sclerosis, said it made an unsolicited $356 million cash takeover bid for a drug partner, Facet Biotech Corporation.
snippet: Biogen, the maker of medicines for multiple sclerosis, said it made an unsolicited $356 million cash takeover bid for a drug partner, Facet Biotech Corporation.
lead_paragraph: Biogen, the maker of medicines for multiple sclerosis, said it made an unsolicited $356 million cash takeover bid for a drug partner, Facet Biotech Corporation. The offer of $14.50 a share is 64 percent more than Facet’s closing price on Thursday. Facet closed at $15.38 on Friday. On Aug. 25, Facet turned down an offer of $15 a share and struck a collaboration with Trubion Pharmaceuticals, Biogen said in a statement. Facet said on Friday that Biogen’s $15 offer was “not in the best interests of stockholders.”

headline.main: Biogen Offers $356 Million for Facet Biotech
headline.print_headline: Biogen Offers $356 Million For Facet Biotech

abstract: The Treasury Department has sent the bankrupt remains of Chrysler a default notice, saying the company did not repay a loan due June 30.
snippet: The Treasury Department has sent the bankrupt remains of Chrysler a default notice, saying the company did not repay a loan due June 30.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department has sent the bankrupt remains of Chrysler a default notice, saying the company did not repay a loan due June 30. The department sent the notice on Aug. 13, according to old Chrysler, now known as Old Carco, in a bankruptcy court filing. The government lent Old Carco $3.34 billion to complete its bankruptcy, the filing said. Old Carco said it was negotiating with the Treasury to address the default. The best assets of the old company were sold to a group led by Fiat. Old Carco has now reported an $11.8 billion loss on the Fiat sale, leading to a net loss of $10.2 billion in June, court records show.

headline.main: Chrysler Defaulted on Loan, Treasury Says
headline.print_headline: Chrysler Defaulted On Loan, Treasury Says

abstract: Dish Network and EchoStar were ordered to pay about $200 million to TiVo for contempt of an order that Dish stop providing its digital-video recording service after losing a patent-infringement ruling.
snippet: Dish Network and EchoStar were ordered to pay about $200 million to TiVo for contempt of an order that Dish stop providing its digital-video recording service after losing a patent-infringement ruling.
lead_paragraph: Dish Network, the satellite-television provider, and EchoStar were ordered to pay about $200 million to TiVo for contempt of an order that Dish stop providing its digital-video recording service after losing a patent-infringement ruling. TiVo, a pioneer of DVR services, had sought $974.5 million from Dish for contempt of court in their patent battle of more than five years. TiVo argued it was entitled to keep all the profits Dish received from DVR during that period. The judge also said Dish and EchoStar’s infringement was not willful. EchoStar runs the digital set-top box manufacturing and satellite services businesses that were part of Dish before the companies split. The figure breaks down to $1.25 per subscriber per month, or $110 million, for continued infringement based on a rate set by the jury, plus $1 additional, or $90 million, each in sanctions, the judge said.

headline.main: Dish Network and Echostar Fined $200 Million
headline.print_headline: Dish Network and Echostar Fined $200 Million

abstract: See if you can beat Dan Feyer in this competition puzzle by Mike Nothnagel.

lead_paragraph: There’s a notepad on today’s puzzle that doesn’t affect the solving experience. “This crossword was the playoff puzzle at Lollapuzzoola, a crossword tournament directed by Brian Cimmet and Ryan Hecht, held in Jackson Heights, Queens, on August 22. The winner, Dan Feyer, of New York City, finished it perfectly in 7 minutes 10 seconds.” Don’t worry if you can’t beat Mr. Feyer. He’s very fast.

headline.main: Judging Lollapuzzoola with Deb Amlen

abstract: Bank of America won a bid to continue blocking regulators from gaining access to more than $1 billion in cash and loans held by the bankrupt Colonial BancGroup. Late Friday, a federal judge in Miami extended an injunction barring the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Colonial officials from disposing of the defunct bank’s assets over which Bank of America has a claim. Colonial was closed by regulators and taken over by the BB&T Corporation last month. Bank of America sued Colonial to block its use of the $1 billion, saying that the bank was holding the assets in trust for one of Bank of America’s units.

lead_paragraph: BACK during the Obama transition, the newly designated chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel, enunciated what I’ll call the Emanuel Principle: “You don’t ever want a crisis to go to waste,” he said. “It’s an opportunity to do important things that you would otherwise avoid.” He was right. But I fear that the Emanuel Principle is about to be violated in the case of financial reform.

abstract: BP will complete the survey amid controversy that oil and trade considerations could have played a role in the early release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber, Ali al-Megrahi.
snippet: BP will complete the survey amid controversy that oil and trade considerations could have played a role in the early release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber, Ali al-Megrahi.
lead_paragraph: BP will complete a seismic survey off the coast of Libya next month as it prepares to drill its first well in the North African country in more than 30 years amid controversy that oil and trade considerations could have played a role in Scotland’s early release of the convicted Lockerbie bomber, Ali al-Megrahi, left. BP plans to drill its first Libyan well in the second half of 2010 as part of a $900 million exploration program, a company spokesman, David Nicholas, said on Monday. BP signed an accord with Libya’s National Oil Corporation in May 2007, during a visit by Tony Blair, then the British prime minister. The deal has raised political questions after the Scottish government’s Aug. 20 decision to free on compassionate grounds the terminally ill Mr. Ali, the only Libyan convicted of the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, which killed 270 people. BP’s agreement allows it to explore 21,000 square miles and the company said in 2007 that it planned to drill 17 exploration wells and potentially as many as 20 more.

headline.main: BP Conducts Seismic Survey Off the Coast of Libya
headline.print_headline: BP Conducts Seismic Survey Off the Coast of Libya

abstract: Singapore’s state-controlled Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing sold for $1.8 billion.
snippet: Singapore’s state-controlled Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing sold for $1.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Abu Dhabi agreed to buy Singapore’s state-controlled Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing for $1.8 billion to create a challenger to United Microelectronics of Taiwan as a maker of customized chips. The purchase is being made through Advanced Technology Investment Company, an investment venture owned by Abu Dhabi. It will pa $2.68 Singapore dollars ($1.86) a share in cash, the buyer said in a statement Monday. That is two Singapore cents higher than the chip maker’s closing price on Sept. 4. The purchase could allow Abu Dhabi to combine its Globalfoundries venture with Chartered, the maker of chips that run Microsoft Xbox 360 game consoles. Steven Pelayo, an analyst at HSBC Holdings in Hong Kong, said: “This presents a formidable threat to other players and really does start to change the competitive landscape much more quickly than I thought.”

headline.main: Abu Dhabi to Purchase Chartered Semiconductor
headline.print_headline: Abu Dhabi To Purchase Chartered Semiconductor

abstract: The controversial video and print advertisements comparing the 9/11 attacks with the 2004 tsunami have focused attention on the phenomenon of ads created expressly for award shows.

lead_paragraph: The controversial video and print advertisements comparing the 9/11 attacks with the 2004 tsunami have focused attention on a phenomenon within the advertising industry known as fake, phantom or scam ads. abstract: Credit card borrowing is falling at the fastest pace ever.

Since interest is accumulating every month, that is an impressive accomplishment.

abstract: Dominick Dunne’s memorial service built on great stories about a man who wrote his share of them.
snippet: Dominick Dunne’s memorial service built on great stories about a man who wrote his share of them.
lead_paragraph: Of all of his creative output – films, books, his long-running column in Vanity Fair – Dominick Dunne’s crowning work has always been his own life. His story had the kind of arc that few writers can conjure. After a huge rise and fall in Hollywood as a producer that was accompanied by far too many substances, Mr. Dunne eventually sobered up, only to be confronted by the most unfathomable tragedy anyone can face: the murder of his daughter. After chronicling the trial for Vanity Fair, his second act was unstoppable, yielding books, magazines and an endless list of famous and infamous friends that he doted on and traded gossip with. All of it was lovingly recorded by Mr. Dunne, a serial namedropper who was quick to embrace his own fame before anybody ever heard of Facebook. Friends would talk of his penchant for scrapbooking his own life, of putting photos and invitations between pages as if he himself did not believe his good fortune.

headline.main: Dominick Dunne’s Last Big Story

abstract: If Lehman had been saved, might a more cataclysmic failure occurred?
snippet: If Lehman had been saved, might a more cataclysmic failure occurred?
lead_paragraph: When I was making phone calls for my column this week, two people mentioned Barbara Tuchman’s great book “The Guns of August.” The book is about the chaotic, almost haphazard series of events that led to the outbreak of World War I. One point she makes is that although the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914 was the event that precipitated the war, it was hardly the reason that war broke out. Tension had been building for months — all that was needed was a spark.

headline.main: Lehman Brothers and the Guns of August

lead_paragraph: Columbia University’s endowment investments lost 16.1 percent in the year that ended June 30. The school’s preliminary, unaudited estimate of the endowment’s value is about $5.7 billion, after standard endowment spending of about 4 to 5 percent annually, said Robert Kasdin, senior executive vice president, who oversees school operations. The fund was valued at $7.1 billion on June 30, 2008. The two richest schools in the nation, Harvard University and Yale University, had bigger declines in their funds’ investments over the last fiscal year, according to figures released Thursday.

abstract: Profit fell to $69 million, or 20 cents a share, from $89 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier.
snippet: Profit fell to $69 million, or 20 cents a share, from $89 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: The Campbell Soup Company said Friday that its profit fell 22 percent in its fourth quarter but was better than Wall Street had expected. Profit fell to $69 million, or 20 cents a share, from $89 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, the company earned 30 cents a share, topping the 26 cents expected by analysts. Sales in the period, which ended Aug. 2, fell 11 percent to $1.53 billion, partly because the quarter was one week shorter. Sales of ready-to-serve soups in the United States rose 14 percent. Stock in Campbell, which is based in Camden, N.J., rose 1 cent, to $33.13 a share.

headline.main: Campbell’s Profit Falls, but Tops Forecasts

lead_paragraph: The Associated Press reported yesterday that the ratings for “The Oprah Winfrey Show” were down 7 percent last year, understandable against a backdrop of atomizing audiences, but not something you tend to hear about the invincible Ms. Winfrey. The A.P. points out that other daytimers like Jerry Springer and Martha Stewart are down double digits, which is a little hard to figure given that so many Americans are stuck at home on their couch without a job. But Ms. Winfrey has always managed to defy larger trends, so she is opening her 24th season with a Whitney Houston exclusive and a return of Dr. Phil after seven years. Still, she may be up against some self-created turbulence, according to the A.P.

But online reading might have just picked up a few tricks from the offline world. As Miguel Helft has noted, Google made of a bit of a splash on Monday at the TechCrunch50 conference when they unveiled Fast Flip, an experimental news hub that uses pre-loaded static images of news pages so that readers can quickly scan through an a visually inviting database of news.

lead_paragraph: A little-discussed feature of the Toronto International Film Festival is the tendency of government officials of all sorts to drop in on the proceedings. They have every right. The festival receives support from about a dozen federal, provincial, municipal agencies, including the Canada Council for the Arts and the government of Ontario. Still, it can be a little unnerving to find a minister, mayor or other functionary dropping in to take a bit of credit for the proceedings, and share a good-natured thought about festival choices — like, for instance, one official’s onstage meditation last week about a long-go decision to screen “Prospero’s Books.”

abstract: The Atlantic goes live with a new site that creates a one-stop shop for the pundocracy.
snippet: The Atlantic goes live with a new site that creates a one-stop shop for the pundocracy.
lead_paragraph: What do Paul Krugman, Rush Limbaugh, George Will, Thomas Friedman and David Brooks have in common? Not much, we hear you, but they are actually virtually united as the top five in The Atlantic50, a just-hatched feature of The Atlantic Wire, a new digital franchise dedicated to iterating and serving up fresh printed perspectives. We know, we know, the Web isn’t really short on opinions — everyone with a modem has one — but The Atlantic Wire is an attempt to distill the clutter down to the thinkers and talkers who matter. There are editor’s picks, highlighted topics and all manner of rankings of who is shouting down his or her opponents most effectively.

headline.main: Atlantic Hits the Wire With Lots of Opinions

abstract: It pains me to think of the emotional and financial toll that my hiring mistakes have taken on me, my team and my company.
snippet: It pains me to think of the emotional and financial toll that my hiring mistakes have taken on me, my team and my company.
lead_paragraph: Companies, like people, are complex. On the surface, it’s not always evident what makes someone tick. Dig a little deeper, however, and you might come across something — a passion, a past experience, a goal — that provides an overarching explanation for that person’s actions, statements and decisions. The same is true for companies, which, after all, are made up of people, except for one crucial difference: While it’s O.K., even intriguing, for a person to go through life being mysterious, enigmatic and complex, a company’s motivations need to be clear to all involved, especially job seekers.

headline.main: What You Need to Understand to Improve Your Hiring

abstract: The new owners of Skype had better like their lawyers because it looks as if they’re going to be spending a lot of time with them.

lead_paragraph: When last we left the founders of Skype, Janus Friis and Niklas Zennstrom, they were trying to buy back their baby from eBay, to which they had sold it in 2005. And they were not having much success. (Whether this was because the bid they made with some private equity partners was too low, or because eBay wouldn’t give them the time of day is a matter of considerable dispute.) They were also busy suing eBay, claiming that it was using peer-to-peer technology that remained their intellectual property — and which they no longer wished to license to eBay. Such a move, if upheld by the courts, would effectively shut down Skype.

headline.main: The Skype Story Continues: So Much for Option B

abstract: A year after it became clear that we were suffering through the worst economy most of us can remember, it seems appropriate to ask what small businesses are doing differently.
snippet: A year after it became clear that we were suffering through the worst economy most of us can remember, it seems appropriate to ask what small businesses are doing differently.
lead_paragraph: As we’ve been reminded this week, it has been a full year now since Lehman Brothers collapsed and things really got ugly. It seems an appropriate time to ask what we’ve learned — not about politics or the economy but about running a business. Have you tried ideas that you never would have tried if business had been good? What worked? What didn’t? Are you less likely to manage your business aggressively today? Or more likely? What are the most important lessons you’ve learned?

headline.main: What Have We Learned?

abstract: Do we really need a jobs program for bankers?
snippet: Do we really need a jobs program for bankers?
lead_paragraph: The House voted yesterday, on a largely party-line vote, to cut subsidies for student loans given to banks, and to instead make the loans directly. As I understand it now — and I am not an expert — the government already takes the risk and puts up the cash. So it is not clear to me that this is much of a change in reality. Perhaps the expertise of bank lending officers is needed, but I doubt there is much of that applied when the bank profits from making the loan, not getting it repaid.

headline.main: Student Loans as a Jobs Program

abstract: Rather than cutting jobs, San Francisco restaurants are passing the cost along to their customers.
snippet: Rather than cutting jobs, San Francisco restaurants are passing the cost along to their customers.
lead_paragraph: That is the conclusion reported by National Public Radio, in a piece that aired Tuesday morning. The piece was about a program called Healthy San Francisco, which offers uninsured residents access to a network of neighborhood clinics that emphasize preventive and coordinated care. Healthy San Francisco is financed in part by a mandate on companies with 20 or more employees. Companies with up to 100 workers must pay at least $1.23 for every hour worked by each employee to cover that employee’s health care costs; those companies that don’t provide insurance or other forms of reimbursement pay the minimum to cover the employee’s participation in Healthy San Francisco.

headline.main: Is the Employer Mandate a Job Killer? Not in San Francisco.

abstract: Researchers have found an essentially irrational buyer response to “run length,” meaning the height and depth of a stock’s spikes.
snippet: Researchers have found an essentially irrational buyer response to “run length,” meaning the height and depth of a stock’s spikes.
lead_paragraph: Consider a stock that picks up 10 cents on even days of the month and loses that much on odd days. Now imagine, instead, a stock that picks up value until the midpoint of the month, and then sinks until the endpoint. Both stocks offer the same monthly and yearly return. But investors will tend to regard the first stock as safer than the second, according to a paper soon to be published in The Journal of Consumer Research. The researchers found an essentially irrational buyer response to “run length,” meaning the height and depth of a stock’s spikes, unrelated to the frequency with which the stock varies, the period of time over which the investment is contemplated, the stock’s returns over a given period or its average value.

headline.main: Perceiving the Risk of Stock Picking
headline.print_headline: Perceiving the Risk of Stock Picking

headline.main: Are Entrepreneurs Born or Made?

abstract: Finding your way in Michigan without a daily newspaper roadmap.
snippet: Finding your way in Michigan without a daily newspaper roadmap.
lead_paragraph: This past week, I visited a place that newspapers forgot, or was it the other way around? While working on an article about Time Inc.’s decision to parachute into Detroit for a year, I tried to get used to the fact that the newspapers there  get delivered only three days a week and the other days, it is tough to find them. Too bad, because between a city where stories seem to lie around every corner and with such a really talented bunch of journalists on hand, it would be nice to have a newspaper plop into the middle of things more often. But as Richard Pérez-Peña points out, newspapers are deathly ill, no more so than in a place like Michigan where the implosion of the auto industry has created collateral damage in all sectors of the economy.

headline.main: Missing a Daily Ritual in Michigan

abstract: Resurgent debt markets have helped many refinance loans, keeping them from defaulting, but squeezing their cash flows as interest costs grow.

lead_paragraph: Junk borrowers are trading death row for extended jail time. Resurgent debt markets have helped several high-yield borrowers refinance loans. That will keep them from defaulting when loans come due, averting the possibility of near-term death by bankruptcy. But with interest costs most likely at least doubling, their cash flows will be squeezed  condemning some to protracted penny-pinching, if not worse.

Decoder thought we’d check out the theory at the opening of the Gizmodo Gallery last night, which was held so far downtown that we needed a hipster app on our iPhone to find it. Kidding, the temporary gallery (now open to the public) is just below Houston in Manhattan at 267 Elizabeth Street — we counted three colleagues from the House of Many Doors, so how hip could it really be? — and was jammed to the brim with all manner of needless, heedless, and yes, potentially useful electronic tchotchkes, many of which are apparently sucking the juice out of the grid.

abstract: The Inc. 500/5000 Conference brings together everything from “small giants” to future giants to companies with no future at all.
snippet: The Inc. 500/5000 Conference brings together everything from “small giants” to future giants to companies with no future at all.
lead_paragraph: I am at the Inc. 500/5000 Conference near Washington. I am told that there are about 1,700 entrepreneurs coming to the conference and awards dinner. Given the state of the economy over the past year, I find that encouraging. I have talked to quite a few people already, and I can tell you that it is a cross-section of small business, inside and outside of the United States. Sure, some of the people here are expanding their businesses at a tremendous rate and are going to get an award on Friday night. At the same time, many others have felt the pressure of the bad economy and have seen their sales go down. The common denominator is that everyone is looking forward to insights and inspiration from not only a distinguished list of speakers but from one another. I plan on sharing some of those insights with you as I make my way through the conference.

headline.main: Seeking an Entrepreneurial Recharge

abstract: Gawker publishes McSteamy video, and then publishes suit against it for doing same.
snippet: Gawker publishes McSteamy video, and then publishes suit against it for doing same.
lead_paragraph: As we wrote about on Thursday, Eric Dane, an actor from “Grey’s Anatomy” – aka “Dr. McSteamy” – and his wife Rebecca Gayheart had their attorney Marty Singer file a $1 million suit against Gawker Media for its role in publishing a video of them romping in the altogether. The little imps at Gawker, not ones to let a lawsuit cramp their style, posted the complaint in its entirety. And as it turns out, the actors are not alleging libel, slander or invasion of privacy as a primary cause of the action, but rather that Gawker violated their copyright on the salacious video. The complaint states that “Plaintiffs timely (sic) registered with the United States Copyright Office their rights as authors and owners of the video. The copyright registration number is PAu 3-404-881.”

headline.main: McSteamy Vid Lawsuit? It’s a Copyright Beef

abstract: Lawrence Wright, Pulitzer Prize winning author and New Yorker writer, switches keyboards this weekend and gigs with WhoDo.
snippet: Lawrence Wright, Pulitzer Prize winning author and New Yorker writer, switches keyboards this weekend and gigs with WhoDo.
lead_paragraph: Here at Decoder, we think it’s only fair that people be good at one thing. Given our limited skill set, the threat of multiplatform players is just a little too daunting. With that in mind, can we just say how offended we are that Lawrence Wright, a staff writer for The New Yorker who won a Pulitzer Prize for his ambitious “Looming Tower,” will be gigging in town this Saturday at Hill Country BBQ as the leader of WhoDo, an Austin-based blues and rockabilly band? It’s enough of a task to come to grips with Mr. Wright’s skills at the keyboard and ability to go long and glorious — last spring he wrote a heave about Carlos Slim, the Mexican mogul who bought a piece of a certain little newspaper — but now we find out he pounds a keyboard that makes music as well. And if that isn’t sickening enough, WhoDo, which includes some other hacks turned musicians like John Burnett of NPR, will be backing Ruby Jane Smith, the 14-year-old fiddling phenom who has tongues wagging every which way every time she plays. Most journalists, including those of us at Decoder, are challenged to get a toe tapping in time to the music, so excuse us for not jumping for joy at the specter of journo-journeymen musicians. Honesty and craft compel us to mention that we hear the band is wonderful, but it’s still a bit much, no?

headline.main: Who Do These Guys Think They Are?

abstract: I’m not saying that I need or want to know everyone’s personal problems, but I do want people to know that they can come to me.
snippet: I’m not saying that I need or want to know everyone’s personal problems, but I do want people to know that they can come to me.
lead_paragraph: When you work with a group of people nine hours a day, five days a week, you get to know them pretty well. I can usually tell when someone on my team is upset, frustrated, annoyed or just simply off. Unfortunately, I’ve noticed these emotions coming through more over the past year than ever before, thanks to the strain of the economy. Whether the causes are internal, such as losing a client, or external, such as a spouse losing a job, one person’s negative emotional state can and often does affect everyone else.

headline.main: Keeping Morale Up When the Economy’s Down
